Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 19. Renunciation

The Bodhisattva saw everything with the gaze of the elephant. He said,"For as long as I have not attained the supreme path Taught by all the buddhas, To the city of Kapilavastu I shall not again enter."
Manual - English: The horse, Kaṇṭhaka, is decorated with jewels. Chandaka returns to the palace.  The horse is also known as “Faithful horse” (dad pa gser ldan), hence a trumpeter should be accompanied. This has no truthful basis, but is simply a rumor. Since the Indian drawing is authentic, it should be kept that way.      A hunter offers a robe to the Buddha who then goes to shave his hair himself in front of a stupa. Gods collects hair. All three scenes above are the same as in the mainstream (p.17).      There are sages in a forest with trees of golden leaves. The sages are upset when the forest turns into the “grove of noble trees” (shing 'phags pa'i tshal). The Buddha joins them in the forest.

Sun of Faith - English: He traveled two stages of twelve leagues along the road and then dismounted his horse. He relieved himself of his ornaments and to Chandaka he commanded, " Take these ornaments and my horse are return."
Filled with tears, Chandaka pleaded, "In the wilderness filled with lions and tigers And the tracks of other animals, All alone with no companions, How with the Noble One practice?"

The Bodhisattva said, All beings alone are born in life, And when they die they die alone. Here the lonely are faced with suffering. In samsara no one has companions. Chandaka asked many other questions, and the Bodhisattva offered many responses.
Then, with his sword, like the petals of a blue Utpala lotus, the Bodhisattva cut his hair and tossed it into the sky.
Indra took hair to establish a festival for it in the realm of the gods.
Inscription - English: The hair was carried to the heavens.

Sun of Faith - English: He also had a stupa constructed at that location.
Then Kanthaka the king of horses licked the Bodhisattva's feet with his tongue. And the Bodhisattva patted Kanthaka's head, saying "When I attain enlightenment I will show my gratitude to you."

To Chandaka he said, "Take Kanthaka back to the palace." Choaked up and teary eyed, Chandaka led Kanthaka along. Looking back at the Bodhisattva again and again, they set out. After seven days they wandered back to Kapilavastu. Chandaka thought, "If I go forth together with the horse, I will hear a terrible wailing that will take my breath away and I will die."
So Chandaka stayed in a pleasure garden and sent Kanthaka onward.
Kanthaka neighed, and many people emerged from their homes to look at him. When they did not see the Boddhisattva, they grabbed the king of horses about the neck and wailed and lamented.
Inscription - English: The queen and the people Kanthaka

Sun of Faith - English: Kanthaka breathed his last, and when he died he was reborn into a family that dilligently practiced the six virtues of a brahmin.
Indra then appeared in the guise of an old hunter. He wore a saffon robe that had been passed on from a Solitary Buddha to a tree spirit. Bow and arrow in hand, he waited alongside the road.
The Bodhisattva saw that his fine clothing was not appropriate for renouncing the world, and that this saffron hemp cloth would be best for renunciation. "Let us trade," he said.
Inscription - English: He exhanges his fine Kashika clothing with those a hunter, who is Indra in human form.

Sun of Faith - English: Indra, in the hunter's form, bowed at his feet and offered the saffron robe. He took the Bodhisattva's fine Kashika garments and used them as offerings in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. The Bodhisattva made the wish, "If this saffron robe does not fit my body may it do so," and the robe changed to an appropriate size.
Inscription - English: Indra carries the fine Kashika garments to the heaven realms.

Sun of Faith - English: Now dressed as a renunciate, the Bodhisattva traveled to the retreat center of Bhagamva the sage. At this retreat center the palm and other fruit trees had produced golden flowers, fruits, and leaves for the past twelve years. Yet just this morning they had transformed into ordinary trees.
Inscription - English: Staying at the foot of the white tree of Rajagriha. [incorrect location?]

Sun of Faith - English: The sages there were deep in thought. "Why are you deep in thought?" asked the Bodhisattva. "These golden fruit trees have transformed into ordinary trees."

"The person whose power had transformed the trees of this retreat center into gold has this morning renounced the world," said the Bodhisattva. "He has no need for things such as this, so they have become ordinary. If he had not renounced the world, this grove would have become a pleasure garden."

They scrutinized the Bodhisattva for a long time, thinking that the person whose power had transformed the trees was this very person. They questioned him, and he replied that this was so. Then the sages invited him to sit upon a throne, and served him flowers and fruit.
